topic.title: What would you do if a loved one or someone close to you came to you one day and said...
topic.body:
...that they were a [waifuist](https://reddit.com/r/waifuism)? That they believed they were in a serious committed relationship with a fictional character?

Would you laugh at them? Drive them straight to the nearest mental hospital?

Disclaimer: I'm not a waifuist, nor has this happened to me; I'm just morbidly curious.

1567210251_1GFU4qAMTFnQJ7W7r98Zj2xJWq1ev.body: Posts that are nothing more than just a few racial slurs with no substance to them. At least explain *why* you feel that way.

zeronet spambots require more coding skills than the average skiddie has

1568753767_1GJc2vm4vJjAKsFoFJ2D3gGmKiRac.body:
- it doesn't require a public-facing computer with ports open or a domain name like the clearnet does
- usable on local networks if outgoing connections are limited
- two clicks to make a zite, as opposed to setting up server software, editing config files, etc
- no censorship :)

1568749254_14kTJXu4KZSoWSSNcGtXEijf4NqEG.body:
Not a fan of Krixano by any means (he's quite easily provoked to drama, from my personal experience with him on other platforms), but I welcome any viable alternative to ZeroID and other centralized ZeroNet services.

The blocklists should be separated from KxoID, though, and set to opt-in. "Anti-certain-group" can be rather subjective depending on context (if it was a joke, clear but unmarked sarcasm, etc), plus I don't really trust him to keep a clear and fair head when it comes to who gets on the list.

All the trading rooms require Deluxe to get into nowadays, and that costs $50/year, so not worth it. Back then, any old schmuck could trade.

1573407833_1CLhLYdMKjXtium9yjuRkSnFvPfdo.body: grateful to have found zeronet, so I can sleep easy at night knowing, if I ever lose the ability to host my website at home, it's not the end of the world :)

> [xcape2net](#comment_558_1GJc2vm4vJjAKsFoFJ2D3gGmKiRac2kfnz): I was wondering about the reason for your clearnet site begin down a few days ago.  And, I noticed your ZeroNet zite remained up--of course.  :)

If my clearnet site was down, it was because my router (I host at home) fucks up constantly and blocks my Raspberry Pi from the network. It does that to all the devices in the network at some point, but my server most frequently.

Rebooting seems to temporarily fix it, so I have a line in my crontab to reboot the server every day at 1 AM, but sometimes the network goes down before I can catch it.

Once I finally secure a steady stream of income, I'll probably return to hosting it on a VPS if only for the stability.

1573689881_1BL1pFELvZ58apCLcxogy2W66aC4v.body:
> [root2elroy](#comment_3_12GKd5hKKNsTyxWqE3arbSurnbq6Ek8spk): ... OH EXTREMELY END-SHIT !!Now I know what you mean !!!! With another ZeroNet client, none of my files uploaded to IFS in the last 4 months (!!) are available anymore! My complete IFS-Accont disappeared with all files in the other Z.N. client, although my ZeroNet-Cliend fakes me that !! I've tried it with all the tricks as for example: with and without Tor proxy, Ultrasurf proxy, port release & forwarding rules in the (Fritz Box) Hardware / Rooter, VPN (IKEv2 / LPT / OpenVPN ...) with port release (as UDP or TCP connection) and different DynDNS providers !! IFS is now the twelfth (!) absolutely unreliable ZeroNet project for me !! all twelve ZeroNet projects that I have tested so far proved to be absolutely useless garbage !! ZeroNet project always seem to be extremely smart, useful, functional and smart, but in reality they are just unstable, faulty useless deceptions (joke / cheating) of a very, very small group of developers & supporters that has no real use !! The ZeroNet is just a pre-alpha stage concept, an experiment that pretends to be useful !  [...]

Cranky because you trusted IFS instead of making your own zite, huh?

1574455508_16NS3rBdW9zpLmLSQoD8nLTtNVsRF.body:
> [goodafternoon](#comment_51_1BL1pFELvZ58apCLcxogy2W66aC4vKLfY3): http://127.0.0.1:43110/17aqJNrBjH63D5kgjLLfFi3FZVtW74JDxS/games.html [...]

Could you possibly make the ROM files optional so one can see the selection without having to seed every single file?

Add this line to the site's content.json:
```
"optional": ".*\\.(jpg|jpeg|zip|rar|exe|mobi|pdf|mp4|wmv|mp3|swf|bak|torrent)",
```

and adjust for the file extensions you want to make optional.

Thanks!

1574806526_14dsVvztuXjBxWmk4s4HjUnxuN4Ae.body:
I do a lot of gaming in my free time. More than I'd like to admit.

It used to be one of my favorite things to do, but in recent times I've drifted more towards the /r/StopGaming sentiment of it being a *huge* waste of time for little to no benefit. A surrogate activity, if you will, to compensate for not being able to accomplish much else while housebound.

It doesn't help that my brothers are also huge gamers, to the point of it being the sole defining aspect of their personalities, along with my only IRL friend being huge into gaming as well. If I quit gaming, I'd have little to nothing in common with them left. I'd *like* to sell all my games and systems, but unfortunately I have no way of discreetly getting the boxes and packing materials and shipping labels necessary.

> [styromaniac](#comment_1348_16NS3rBdW9zpLmLSQoD8nLTtNVsRFtVBhd): People don't lose their grip on reality from video games. [...]

Maybe not from video games *in and of themselves*, but their interactive nature makes them a hell of a lot more appealing as an unhealthy coping mechanism. There were a few months of my life where I unironically believed that I was the reincarnation of a video game character, but I probably wouldn't have fallen for that if I hadn't also been facing the stress of starting college at that time.

> [styromaniac](#comment_1351_16NS3rBdW9zpLmLSQoD8nLTtNVsRFtVBhd): Have you talked to a doctor about this? That's a mental disorder worth attention.

If you're referring to the last part, it was a year ago and I've long since moved past it.

> [xcape2net](#comment_578_1GJc2vm4vJjAKsFoFJ2D3gGmKiRac2kfnz): Your brothers will grow out of their gaming fixation in a few years.  [...]

They're both autistic, so it's highly unlikely, but thanks for the optimism.

> [styromaniac](#comment_1355_16NS3rBdW9zpLmLSQoD8nLTtNVsRFtVBhd): [...] One friend of mine from one of those bad families supposedly thinks a wall is his dad now. Imagine the abuse he must have suffered from his father, [...]

Like, a literal, physical wall?

1574608682_1CYE9ryvvXCW4CJPX51T24BFD62cy.body: Not liking how Linux isn't officially supported, and I couldn't get the .snap I downloaded from the website to install due to a missing signature error.

1575342587_17bfQv5PQW9FZ4akChr7ECfqP2SKu.body:
What I do is:
1. keep a clean copy of the zeronet repo
2. make a copy whenever I want to surf for new zites
3. bookmark the zites I like and want to keep
4. nuke the copy
5. seed the bookmarks on my main zeronet setup

> [nickwa](#comment_445_1EFZ3dYDWVpD4kF5H9PF83HjPAehEEKKJj): Use a RAMDisk or use Tails if you want to really do that. Just make it so the RAMDisk or Tails doesn't actually save anywhere else. I mean, it's cool to have the option, but in the meantime, you can use that option.

ZeroNet doesn't work in Tails yet. I've tried both the bundle and the AppImage version. Both fail complaining about bridge support and tell me to upgrade to the latest version of ZeroNet, even though I *am* on the latest version.

It's a problem I'm working on, but it'll take a while before ZeroNet works in Tails.

1575997351_1MnNwuGMC3rxUG8QHmgQiBYJ3o4JZ.body:
Taken from the [FAQ](https://u.is/en/faq.html):

> We may disclose certain parts of code, specifically related to communication and encryption. However, the decentralized protocol will not be released. Utopia is very knowledge-intensive software. A lot of time, effort and resources went into this product, and we do not want to share all of our know-how as it will result in forks which in turn may result in instability of our main network. Fork will lead to the division of the community, while our intention is the unification of the community of like-minded individuals. **The bottom line here is that a lot of software is closed source**, and this does not hurt them a bit. In addition, we will audit our code.

So Utopia is closed-source.

> Utopia has been developed by a group of networking technology enthusiasts over the last 6 years. **To eliminate any impact on the project, developers of Utopia will forever remain anonymous.**

So it's closed-source, *and* we don't know who made it?

This shit glows to high hell. Don't use it, unless you *want* to get fucked in the ass by the feds.

> [0010001100100001](#comment_8_1SNukFwksAnncCiRAnG4996tagosfhSE4): Have you taken a moment to see that url? u.is like a work of art.   [...]

yes, because a pretty url is MUCH better than actually being able to see the source code. /s

1575858185_1PE7nD7YtXWzNdc1EggdBPaqWTYs6.body:
> [fke13](#comment_29_1DZBbYJmuFQvVTe2X2Enrveziw3vN1JQXz): Do not forget that the ZeroNet does NOT provide anonymity, unless tunneled through Tor. For non-anonymous options, let's say, in a situation, where You use some VPN to some western countries for all of Your internet traffic, You may also try out thehttps://beakerbrowser.com/

Dat isn't any more anonymous by default, since, in my tests, it exposes IPs just as much as ZeroNet.

If anything, ZeroNet is *more* anonymous overall since you can use the Tor Browser (with some configuration) and you can use the "Tor always" mode.

1576010387_15BMZ4Rh545Ar7cRQo31FDfc9zC34.body: The [ZeroNet Moderated Directory](/18QPAtqyoxriNcNAi4mkCHyoLENwTEbFyw/) is a good place to find zites to seed.

1576021462_1K8NrwqEfy49zAMWzHgywnToZib7P.body:
ZeroNet can't (easily) be used as an outproxy. It most certainly wouldn't work for your use case.

Tor or I2P might be more up your alley.

1576018469_1PE7nD7YtXWzNdc1EggdBPaqWTYs6.body: I use a text file but format all the links in markdown so they're clickable when I open the file in a markdown viewer.

> [clearnet15bad](#comment_54_1PE7nD7YtXWzNdc1EggdBPaqWTYs6jdkK7): What markdown reader do you use?

For larger markdown files, I use Okular.

Smaller files (like the bookmark file) I send to w3m with `pandoc bookmarks.md | w3m -T text/html` and then I can click them in my terminal to send to a browser.

1576026161_17ZnSRGrALWLigjaDhkzUM4KAC8c8.body:
If you have a VPS, you could install ZeroNet there and then access it though a browser so all traffic/storage happens on the VPS instead of your computer. Check the [documentation](/1DocsYf2tZVVMEMJFHiDsppmFicZCWkVv1/faq/) on what to put in the configuration file.

Otherwise you might be out of luck.

[I2P support is still being worked on, but development for that feature is currently dormant.](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/issues/45)

> [mg0](#comment_194_1LbP2cNA6NkvuFJvs7McUmv9qGjkNqVkTa): HOLD UP RIGHT THERE!!Remember some zites do actually share CP and if you browse irresponsibly you could end downloading it too and seeding it (and then LEA ask the VPS company and shit hits the fan for you). You could have your storage medium encrypted but your whole OS is handled by a 3rd party so it's probably futile. My recommendation is to keep zeronet locked down to localhost in your VPS and access it only through an SSH socks tunnel. And be wary of zites

Shit, should have put a disclaimer on that. I use blacklists religiously, so I completely forgot about the CP issue.

> [sublime6](#comment_1_152JLSuJAhrKabbvowpHjq5W6TzpxmYW3w): is using zeronet on tor.. like torrrenting on tor?they say you shouldn't do that.if you can't then why not just use vpn instead.

The main reason why they say not to torrent on tor is bandwidth issues. If everyone's downloading multi-gigabyte movies over Tor, the network will be slow as hell for everyone. ZeroNet over Tor is fine.

1575869182_1MXVsMNFA5sP6AbbVirbrjzWsMeWy.body: Think of it like torrenting, but for websites. And instead of passwords, you use a Bitcoin public/private key pair.

1576012034_1BL1pFELvZ58apCLcxogy2W66aC4v.body:
> [moor](#comment_335_17zoTjVZEBUdo6uAvQvtbih7ibBMHQRsrH): not sure, its a surprise every time... if on windows i would recommend that you install python3.6 (which comes with pip) on windows and use pip to install the remaining libraries listed inside the requirements.txt through the command prompt, e.g: pip install gsutil [...]

or `pip3 install -r requirements.txt` works too.

1575869098_1MXVsMNFA5sP6AbbVirbrjzWsMeWy.body:
> [fke13](#comment_31_1DZBbYJmuFQvVTe2X2Enrveziw3vN1JQXz): [...] For example, the ZeroNet node can be run on a Linux machine that does not have any GUI/X11 installed by tunneling the 127.0.0.1:43110 over an SSH connection, but as of 2019_12 I'm not sure, if something like that can be easily done with the Dat/Beakerbrowser tools.

There *is* [Homebase](https://github.com/beakerbrowser/homebase) to seed dat sites on a server, but it requires a bunch of Node bullshit to run, and it always crashed whenever I tried to set it up.

1576265919_16NS3rBdW9zpLmLSQoD8nLTtNVsRF.body: Problem is, what do you do about devices that don't support Bluetooth?

1575755429_1DfbNohg1UZxEJXMGS4W46bSSh3Ag.body:
> [styromaniac](#comment_1424_16NS3rBdW9zpLmLSQoD8nLTtNVsRFtVBhd): Is it possible to register a domain to your site on 0net.io? Which registrars allow that? How easy is it? [...]

I know Namecheap allows a URL redirection record in the DNS settings.

Failing that, you could have an index.html that only contains a [meta redirect](https://mediatemple.net/community/products/dv/204645160/how-do-i-redirect-my-site-using-a-meta-tag) to wherever you want the user to go.

> [styromaniac](#comment_1431_16NS3rBdW9zpLmLSQoD8nLTtNVsRFtVBhd): 0net.io is still too slow, to my disappointment, so I have another related question. [...]

You could view-source https://zeronet.link , copy the source code, and then edit it to redirect to kave.video .
Clarification, since people seem to be confused: I didn't make zeronet.link .

> [sublime6](#comment_3_152JLSuJAhrKabbvowpHjq5W6TzpxmYW3w): why not just host it as a normal website with apache? [...]

[Caddy](https://caddyserver.com) is a lot easier to use than Apache.

1576322123_17ZnSRGrALWLigjaDhkzUM4KAC8c8.body:
> [fke13](#comment_44_1DZBbYJmuFQvVTe2X2Enrveziw3vN1JQXz): I just took a look at the lokinet.org. The way I see it, the reason, why the classical HTML and www took over the world and initially from feature set point of view at least as good or superior solutions like the [...]

I was able to set up a hidden service without paying any crypto, so I don't know what part of the documentation you got stuck on.

> [falconixx](#comment_10_17ZnSRGrALWLigjaDhkzUM4KAC8c8rv8Eu): did you install on Linux as guide?

I followed the guide [here](https://docs.loki.network/Lokinet/Guides/lokinet-linux-guide/) to install and [here](https://docs.loki.network/Lokinet/Guides/HostingSNApps/) to set up a hidden service on my VPS.

> [fke13](#comment_46_1DZBbYJmuFQvVTe2X2Enrveziw3vN1JQXz): Start with the main page, where they talk about "governance fee". There are no free lunches, even if the setup is smooth. Besides, the GMail is also "free". No visible fees for the end users.

Can you point me exactly to where it says stuff about "governance fees"? The only stuff I could find about it (which was *not* on the main page, by the way) was if you wanted to use the cryptocurrency part of Lokinet, which I'm not (just using the hidden service part).

1576507403_12yk6fSLY85rKGkemD5wSDAiNvcXG.body:
> With data connection, internet Ap, wifi, vpn, whatever you call it.

These are all different and separate things.

> Still need internet to go to 0net. Still waiting for a mesh network.

From my tests, ZeroNet works just fine over a mesh network. Some of the *trackers* might not work without a functioning DNS system, though, but trackers aren't absolutely necessary since you can still access zites you and your local peers are seeding.

1576697039_1JorDyDxuLrircDbzzmn4B1ndcbSJ.body:
> [thewhispering](#comment_16_1JorDyDxuLrircDbzzmn4B1ndcbSJahXLH): How would I go about setting up a forum software? Let's say that I wanted to install a Simple Machines Forum(SMF Platform) or any other forum package(Vbulletin,Zenforo,etd.) I am confused on how to create my own Zites using the software I am familiar with. [...]

You can't use traditional server-client website software on ZeroNet. It simply won't work since zites don't use a single server.

You *could* try a static HTML generator like Jekyll or Hugo if you just want a basic site, but something like a forum (from scratch) will take a hell of a lot of CoffeeScript. Most people just clone ZeroTalk and edit that.

1577433117_1Drej4kKBea1TryGPYfVZgzDxaB71.body:
> [fib](#comment_27_1Drej4kKBea1TryGPYfVZgzDxaB71rsKkK): [...] There's no way a computer with 8 cores and 64GB of ram could run as slowly as modern handhelds are prone to! [...]

Do you know if it's a software or hardware problem? How many programs are you running in the background?

What I would do is boot into a clean live USB, and if problems persist, then it's probably a hardware problem. If not, then something's wonky with your main operating system.

> [fib](#comment_27_1Drej4kKBea1TryGPYfVZgzDxaB71rsKkK):  [...] I watched a 64kb video that was 10 minutes long at the turn of the century. [...]

What encoding was the video using?

> [fib](#comment_32_1Drej4kKBea1TryGPYfVZgzDxaB71rsKkK): Mobile phones are the computers I'm referring to, as they purposefully have restricted interfaces where background tasks can be easily hidden.

What kind of a phone is it? If you have an Android, you can use ADB to view all the system apps installed on the device and purge the ones that look shady (although, without root, they'll come back during a factory reset).

I used ADB to forcibly remove all the Google apps from my Android phone, and the amount of telemetry traffic dropped to nearly zero.

Edit: if you're not using Google services, this doesn't remove any functionality. You might get some "This app doesn't work without Google Play Services" notifications, but most of them are false and the app works just fine, and the notifications are easily silenced anyway.

1577567502_1NZftAz9VSawGF5JgMYGFv4ByoKEa.body:
> Solution: Introduce a time limit on all posts. Allow only 1-2 posts per day

This requires centralization and a closed-source base. Pretty sure people here hate both of those things. And if the source code is available, there will inevitably be a fork that allows for more frequent posts.

If the goal is to rehabilitate Twitter, then it still won't work because people will just make alt accounts to get more tweets per day.

It's a nice idea, though.

1577824395_1NZftAz9VSawGF5JgMYGFv4ByoKEa.body:
> I don't want Generation Alphas to inherit a narcissistic, individualistic world

There's nothing wrong with being an individual. And there's nothing wrong with **voluntarily** joining a group or collective.

The problem is when one is forced into a group they don't want to be associated with, or when forces beyond their control atomize them and prevent them from joining forces with others to solve problems they feel are important.

I wish more people understood this and stopped using "individualism" as a dirty word.

Narcissism, however, is still a shitty thing, although it is a damn fine line between that and self-love.

1577893728_16m8gAt3tZc2tssxPz2zzuz873Ez8.body:
My family always calls me grumpy for not buying into the whole Marvel/Star Wars/Doctor Who spectacle shitshow.

And we have two dogs, and they constantly shit everywhere and bark at all hours of the day, and I get called grumpy for not acting like they're precious perfect angels.

And the appeal of most modern mainstream memes has worn off for me. I'm sick and tired of hearing about Fortnite and dabbing and Shrek this Shrek that.

Maybe I'm just a grumpy old woman.

1579271298_1G8B8kPwDH69FMuSPEvNkG8JJy5Px.body:
Include them with your zite, but make them optional with this line in your `content.json`:

```
"optional": ".*\\.(jpg|jpeg|zip|rar|exe|mobi|pdf|mp4|wmv|mp
3|swf|bak|torrent)",
```

Adjust the file types to match what you want to host.
